course_title: Multivariate Data Analysis & Machine Learning in Biology

learning_outcomes.description: Manipulate, visualise and analyse realistic, large ecological datasets
Understand the applications of supervised and unsupervised learning and how to implement them
Communicate complex analyses to a general audience
Identify appropriate analytical techniques for diverse biological problems
Use R to perform analyses on complex multivariate datasets
Understand multivariate data structures and summary statistics

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to complete short quizzes on Blackboard. Each quiz consists of multiple choice, short answer or similar types of questions. Please refer to the Blackboard announcements for the assessment link and further details.

There will be six quizzes in total. Only your best five scores will count toward your final grade. Each quiz is worth 4%.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please see Blackboard annoucement for details of this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Late submission penalties do not apply to assessment that have a timer and are automatically submitted or take-home assessments. If you experience demonstrable system and/or process issues beyond your control that prevent you from completing an assessment, you may apply for exemption of the late penalty.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Mid-Semester School-Based Exam

Students will sit an exam which covering material from Weeks 1 to 5 of the course.

This exam is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Written report (1,000 words), critical interpretation of an existing analysis / results section.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Online submission by Turnitin only by the due date and time. Refer to Blackboard for the submission link. No hard copy or assignment cover sheets are required. Submission via email is not accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Foundations in supervised learning

Foundation concepts including: bias-variance trade-off, over-fitting, cross-validation, precision and recall, classification and regression (Letten)
learning_activities.topic_description: Foundations in supervised learning Foundation concepts including: bias-variance trade-off, over-fitting, cross-validation, precision and recall, classification and regression (Letten)

learning_activities.topic:
Logistic classification

Introduction to different supervised learning algorithms: k-nearest neighbours, naive Bayes, support vector machines, decision/regression trees and random forests, and neural networks (Letten)
learning_activities.topic_description: Logistic classification Introduction to different supervised learning algorithms: k-nearest neighbours, naive Bayes, support vector machines, decision/regression trees and random forests, and neural networks (Letten)

learning_activities.topic:
Bestiary of algorithms

Decision and regression tree basics and ensemble learning (Letten)
learning_activities.topic_description: Bestiary of algorithms Decision and regression tree basics and ensemble learning (Letten)
